She said it was strange how the mass of the piles of sugar stayed the same but actually that’s very normal. When you have a reaction, you can’t gain or lose mass so you’ll end up with equal reactants and products. The reason we don’t always see this is because is a product is a gas it can tend to just float away in the air unless you have a method to contain it

7:50 correction here. The reaction between KM­nO₄ and sugar does lose mass, though very little, C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁ + 16KM­nO₄ = 16M­nO₂ + 8K₂­CO₃ + 11H₂O + 4CO₂, both the carbondioxide and water are of course lost, which when you calculate out their masses it amounts to about a 13% lower mass after the reaction has taken place (if the reaction is stoichiometric, or balanced)
Maybe show people why they shouldn't store glycerine next to potassium permangenate in the medicines cabinet...  spoiler alert... 🔥

if you really wanna test the rocket fuels comparatively, you need to see how much gas they create from the same amount of fuel. there are plenty of channels that show examples of how to set up a test like that. compare how much gas is made and how long it took to burn away, and whichever produces a higher volume of gas in less time is the better fuel. a burn on a plate doesnt really show much in terms of viability as a rocket fuel. i also think it'd be interesting to test pixie sticks since they are mostly made of glucose (dextrose),  should be a simpler sugar for the reaction to break down more quickly. candy hearts also contain dextrose, but there's also a bunch of corn syrup and binders as well, that might even be hindering the potential.

For anyone interested, the chemical reaction for the sulfuric acid with the sugar is as follows:
C12H22O11(s) + H2SO4(l) -> 12C(s) + 11H2O(l) + H2SO4(l) [Sulfuric acid dehydrates the sugar]
H2O(l) + H2SO4(l) -> 2H+(aq) + SO4{2-}(aq) + H2O(g) + HEAT [Sulfuric acid dissolves in water generating tremendous amounts of heat]
